channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Michel Temer, Brazil’s Interim President, May Herald Shift to the Right
item.media:description: Michel Temer, Brazil’s interim president, at the inauguration of his newly appointed ministers.
item.description: Mr. Temer’s first pick for science minister was a creationist, and he is the first Brazilian leader in decades to have no women in his cabinet.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Brazil’s Senate Votes to Begin Impeachment Trial of Dilma Rousseff
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff this month. Describing the effort to remove her as a coup, Ms. Rousseff, the first woman to be president of Brazil, has repeatedly rejected calls to resign.
item.description: The lawmakers voted on Thursday to suspend Ms. Rousseff, whose sagging fortunes embody widespread anger at corruption and a battered economy.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS and SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Brazil Workers’ Party, Leaders ‘Intoxicated by Power,’ Falls From Grace
item.media:description: Supporters of the Workers’ Party demonstrating last month in Brasília. The fall of the party, which was once devoted to transparency and clean government, has deepened public mistrust of Brazilian politics.
item.description: A vote to suspend President Dilma Rousseff has dealt a crippling blow to a party that came to power vowing to represent the masses but became ensnared in corruption scandals.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Pope Francis Says Panel Will Study Whether Women May Serve as Deacons
item.media:description: Pope Francis arrived for an assembly of leaders of female Catholic religious congregations on Thursday at the Vatican.
item.description: His comments, revealing an openness to re-examine the church’s insistence on an all-male clergy, were hailed as a breakthrough by women who have clamored for more of a role.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.category: United States Conference of Catholic Bishops

item.title: German Lawmaker Reads Poem on Erdogan, to Show Just How Vulgar It Is
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, left, in February, and the German comedian Jan Böhmermann in 2012.
item.description: A lawmaker read out in Parliament a crude verse insulting Turkey’s president — for which the German comedian who wrote it faces trial — to highlight how offensive it is.
item.dc:creator: VICTOR HOMOLA

item.title: Britain Plans to Tighten Oversight of the BBC in New Charter
item.media:description: The BBC headquarters in London. The proposed charter secures the BBC’s funding through the next charter and will allow the license fee paid by most Britons, frozen at 145.50 pounds a year, to rise with inflation.
item.description: The government, presenting its plans for the BBC’s future, pulled back from radical changes but urged the publicly funded broadcaster to be more “distinctive” in its programming.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Advocating a War in Iraq, and Offering an Apology for What Came After
item.media:description: In his new book, “The Rope,” the author Kanan Makiya used fiction to express his regrets for his role in the aftermath of the United States’ invasion of Iraq in 2003.
item.media:credit: Jodi Hilton for The New York Times
item.description: For Kanan Makiya, an intellectual who helped make the case for the 2003 invasion, writing a novel became a way to acknowledge his role in what befell his home country.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Mustafa Badreddine, Hezbollah Military Commander, Is Killed in Syria
item.media:description: Mustafa Amine Badreddine died in a “huge blast” near the Damascus airport, the group’s television network said.
item.description: Mr. Badreddine, 55, had been accused in the 2005 assassination of a former prime minister of Lebanon, and many other attacks.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Iran Says It Will Avoid the Hajj This Year, Blaming Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: A funeral service in Tehran last year for pilgrims killed in a stampede during the hajj in Saudi Arabia.
item.description: Saudi Arabia, which hosts the hajj, a Muslim pilgrimage, said Iran was to blame for the problem, reflecting the worsening relationship between the countries.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Yoweri Museveni and Other African ‘Presidents for Life’
item.media:description: Robert Mugabe
item.description: The Ugandan president was sworn in for a fifth term. President Obama has urged African leaders not to cling to power, to limited effect.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN, MADELEINE KRUHLY and HANNAH OLIVENNES
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Anticorruption Campaign in China Snares Former Top Party Official
item.media:description: Ling Jihua, who was once the equivalent of the White House chief of staff, has been charged with taking bribes, illegally obtaining state secrets and abuse of power.
item.description: Ling Jihua, who was once the equivalent of the White House chief of staff, has been charged with taking bribes, illegally obtaining state secrets and abuse of power.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Beijing Tries to Whip Up Support for Its South China Sea Claims
item.media:description: A fisherman on Scarborough Shoal. Concern is growing that China may try to build an island on the shoal, which is close to Manila and to bases in the Philippines used by the United States.
item.description: China has been taking its case to the international news media ahead of court decision in a suit filed by the Philippines that challenges Beijing’s claims.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Apple Raises Bet on China as It Faces Scrutiny From Beijing
item.media:description: A Chinese taxi driver using a Didi smartphone app in Beijing las year.
item.description: A $1 billion investment in the Didi Chuxing ride-hailing app enlarges the American giant’s Asian footprint.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Worker Slain at Australian Embassy in Baghdad
item.description: A private security contractor, who was not identified, was reportedly shot.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Navy Reassigns Officer Who Commanded Sailors Detained by Iran
item.media:description: A photo released by the Revolutionary Guards on Jan. 13 showed detained American sailors in an undisclosed location in Iran.
item.description: The officer was relieved of his duties because the Navy had lost “confidence in his ability to command,” the service said in a statement.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: In Syria, an Aid Convoy Is Refused Entry to a Besieged Town
item.description: Syrian government officials at a checkpoint near the rebel-held town of Daraya turned away the convoy, carrying baby formula and medicine.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Once Again, Thieves Enter Swift Financial Network and Steal
item.media:description: Atiur Rahman, a former Bangladesh Bank governor, in March. Details about a second attack involving the messaging system, Swift, are emerging as investigators try to solve an $81 million heist from the central bank of Bangladesh in February.
item.description: Investigators are still trying to solve the $81 million cyberheist from the central bank of Bangladesh in February.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL CORKERY
item.category: SWIFT (Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication)

item.title: W.H.O.’s Zika Guidelines Don’t Include Delaying Olympics
item.media:description: A worker from a cleaning company, wearing a T-shirt that reads “Out Zika,” in April at a site for the Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro.
item.description: The World Health Organization urged athletes and travelers visiting Brazil to take precautions, but has resisted calls to reschedule the Games.
item.dc:creator: PAM BELLUCK

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 6 in Northeastern Nigeria
item.media:description: A paramilitary officer arrived at the scene of a suicide bomb attack in Maiduguri, Nigeria, on Thursday.
item.description: The attacker was stopped outside a heavily guarded government compound in the city of Maiduguri before setting off his explosives.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and SUNDAY ISUWA

item.title: Brazil’s Impeachment Trial of Dilma Rousseff: Readers React
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil waved to supporters in Brasília on Thursday after the Senate voted to impeach her over accusations she broke budget laws.
item.description: The decision stirred a strong response, with some speaking of “dark times for Brazil” and others saying “her removal means hope for the people.”
item.dc:creator: TALYA MINSBERG

item.title: Russia Calls New U.S. Missile Defense System a ‘Direct Threat’
item.media:description: NATO’s secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, center; Prime Minister Dacian Ciolos of Romania, right; and Foreign Minister Lazar Comanescu at Thursday’s opening of an antimissile system.
item.description: The Russian reaction to the opening of the system included suggestions by some commentators that it had raised the risks of a nuclear war.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ISIS Kills Dozens in Iraq in New Round of Bombings
item.description: A day after the Islamic State staged a deadly wave of bombings in Baghdad, its forces struck Ramadi and the capital again.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and OMAR AL-JAWOSHY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Matter: Climate Change and the Case of the Shrinking Red Knots
item.media:description: Foraging red knots in Mauritania.
item.description: A ripple effect of weather, insects and other food supplies, from the Arctic to the tropics, may be driving down the population of the red knot, a study finds.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER

item.title: Letter From Europe: The Imperialist Roots of Our Modern Crises
item.media:description: A campaign bus for Vote Leave in Exeter, England, this week. On June 23, voters in Britain will decide in a referendum whether to quit the European Union.
item.description: The seeds that were sowed as Western powers like Britain faded after the world wars have contributed to the persistent problems of the present.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: France’s Socialist Government Survives a Vote, but Remains Fractured
item.media:description: Tear gas hung in the air in Paris on Thursday during a protest against an overhaul of French labor law.
item.description: President François Hollande’s government survived a vote of no confidence, but with his re-election chances appearing slim, a goal has become resolving the deep ideological split in his party.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Russian Insider Says State-Run Doping Fueled Olympic Gold
item.media:description: The director of Russia’s antidoping laboratory at the time of the Sochi Games said urine samples were surreptitiously replaced by somehow breaking into supposedly tamper-proof bottles.
item.description: Each night, said the director of the antidoping lab at the Sochi Games, bottles of urine were passed through a hole in the wall and replaced for testing the next day.
item.dc:creator: REBECCA R. RUIZ and MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: Personal Data of Prominent Chinese Posted on Twitter
item.media:description: A man using the Internet at a cafe in Shanghai.
item.description: The social media network suspended an account on Thursday after private information about government officials and billionaires was published.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Rome Journal: For Chinese Police Officers, Light Duty on Tourist Patrol in Italy
item.media:description: Pang Bo, center, and Li Xiang, both Chinese police officers, posed for pictures with Chinese tourists in front of the Colosseum in Rome.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: As China and Italy try to nurture closer economic ties, they also want to ease anxieties over petty crime against Chinese visitors to Rome and Milan.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Man’s Death in Custody Prompts Suspicion of Police Brutality
item.description: The police say that Lei Yang, 29, who was seized at a Beijing foot massage parlor, died of a heart attack after resisting arrest.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Sinosphere: China Pressed on Queen Elizabeth II’s Complaint of ‘Very Rude’ Officials
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II speaking with a Metropolitan police commander, Lucy D’Orsi, left, during a garden party at Buckingham Palace on Tuesday.
item.description: The British monarch’s sharp words resonated online, and journalists asked a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for a response.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Dilma Rousseff Was Not Impeached, Legal Scholars Say
item.media:description: Former President Bill Clinton with President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil during the Clinton Global Initiative Latin America meeting in Rio de Janeiro in 2013.
item.description: Not every nation agrees on what an impeachment means. And not each case turns out badly for the defendant, as several recent cases have demonstrated.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: What in the World: Japan Has a Kit Kat for Every Taste, and Then Some
item.media:credit: Illustration by Craig Allen; Photos by Nestlé Japan
item.description: There are nearly 300 varieties of Kit Kat in Japan, where the candy is so popular that it is sold at high-end department stores, Kit Kat-only shops and even post offices.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: What in the World: The Wrong Day to Be a Cat in Belgium
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht; Photo by Inna Astakhova / shutterstock.com
item.description: The people of Ypres, Belgium, once dealt with feral cats by throwing them off a bell tower. Today, they host a cat-themed celebration instead.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: What in the World: Look Out, Celebrity Chefs. Here Comes Kim Jong-un.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Antonio de Luca; Photo by KCNA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Entities linked to North Korea run an expanding empire of restaurants abroad, pumping badly needed profits back to the North.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS

item.title: Q&A: Questions and Answers on Brazil’s Presidential Crisis
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil in the capital, Brasilia, on Tuesday.
item.description: What is Dilma Rousseff accused of doing, and what are the legal justifications for trying to impeach her?
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: Can a New President Lead Sri Lanka Into an Era of Peace?
item.media:description: President Maithripala Sirisena of Sri Lanka in his office in Colombo, the capital. He has pledged to persuade his Sinhalese people to support a new Constitution that devolves the powers of the central government that they dominate.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: President Maithripala Sirisena, chosen by a coalition because he was agreeable and self-effacing, is trying to forge a political solution that for decades has been out of reach.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and DHARISHA BASTIANS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: David Cameron Leads a Call to Thwart Financial Corruption
item.description: Mr. Cameron, representing Britain, outlined measures to fight offshore tax evasion as he met with Secretary of State John Kerry and other leaders in London.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Sadiq Khan and the Future of Europe
item.media:credit: Jonathan Brady/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: London’s new Muslim mayor is a model for integration and acceptance. The Continent should pay attention.
item.dc:creator: MEHDI HASAN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on the Vote to Impeach Dilma Rousseff
item.description: Brazilians react to the Senate vote to suspend the president and begin an impeachment trial against her.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Arab Withering
item.description: How the civic spirit of the Arab Spring gave way to the brutal theocracy of the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
